4.1 Divisibility and Modular Arithmetic

Definition: Divides


Let a, b âZ\in \mathbb{Z}âZ. We say a divides b.
denoted, a|b if âkâZ\exists k\in \mathbb{Z}âkâZ such that b=aâkb = a \cdot kb=aâk

e.g.
\quad \quad 3|9 because 9 = 3 â\cdotâ 3
\quad \quad 2â¤\nmidâ¤9 because âk\nexists kâk such that 9 = 2 â\cdotâ kkk

Example 1

Let n, d âZ\in \mathbb{Z}âZ such that n â¥\geqâ¥ d. How many positive integers not exceeding n, are divisible by d?
n=9n = 9n=9 d=6d = 6d=6 I={1,2,â¦,9}I = \{1,2,\ldots, 9\}I={1,2,â¦,9}
Answer: 6 in III is the only number divisible by 6


6kkk, kâZk \in \mathbb{Z}kâZ
Goal: 6kâ¤k \leqkâ¤ 9 for which values of k?
â\Rightarrowâ kâ¤96k \leq \frac{\mathrm 9}{\mathrm 6}kâ¤â6ââ9ââ
â\Rightarrowâ kâ¤k \leqkâ¤ 1
â\Rightarrowâ kkk = 1{\color{red}1}1, only one that satisfies.

e.g.
n=9n = 9n=9 d=6d = 6d=6 All numbers divisible by 2 have the form

2kkk, kâZk \in \mathbb{Z}kâZ

2kâ¤92k \leq 92kâ¤9

âk=1\Rightarrow k = {\color{red}1}âk=1 or 2{\color{red}2}2 or 3{\color{red}3}3 or 4{\color{red}4}4

For general nnn and ddd, all numbers divisible by ddd have the form

dâkkâZd \cdot k \quad\quad\quad k \in \mathbb{Z}dâkkâZ

\quad \quad\quad \quad\quad \quad\quad \quad\quad \quad\quadRestriction:

dkâ¤ndk \leq ndkâ¤n
âkâ¤nd\Rightarrow k \leq \frac{\mathrm n}{\mathrm d}âkâ¤âdâânââ
range:1,2â¦ândârange: 1,2 \ldots \lfloor \frac{\mathrm n}{\mathrm d} \rfloorrange:1,2â¦ââdâânâââ

Theorem


Let a, b, c âZ\in\mathbb{Z}âZ, where a â \neqâ  0.
Then

1. if a | b and a |c, then a | (b + c)
2. if a | b, then a | bc, âcâZ\forall c \in \mathbb{Z}âcâZ
3. if a | b and b | c, then a | c

e.g.

  1. if 3 | 9 and 3 | 6, then 3 | (6 + 9)

  2. if 3 | 9 and 3 | (9 â\cdotâ 2)

  3. if 3 | 9 and 3 | 18 then 3 | 18

Proof

1. a | b ââkâZ\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z}ââkâZ \quad b = a â\cdotâ k by definition
a | c ââqâZ\rightarrow \exists q \in \mathbb{Z}ââqâZ \quad c = a â\cdotâ q by definition
\quad
âb+c=aâk+aâq\Rightarrow b + c = a \cdot k + a \cdot qâb+c=aâk+aâq
b+c=aâ(k+q)\quad b + c = a \cdot (k + q)b+c=aâ(k+q)
b+c=aâ(p)pâZ\quad\quad\quad\quad b + c = a \cdot (p) \quad\quad\quad p\in\mathbb{Z}b+c=aâ(p)pâZ
â\Rightarrowâ a | (b + c)
â \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquareâ 
\quad

2. a | b ââkâZ\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quadââkâZ
b === a â\cdotâ k \quad\quad\quad\quad
bâc=aâkâcâcâZb \cdot c = a \cdot k \cdot c \quad \forall c \in \mathbb{Z}bâc=aâkâcâcâZ
=aâppâZp=kc\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad = a \cdot p \quad\quad p \in \mathbb{Z} \quad p = kc=aâppâZp=kc
â\Rightarrowâ a | bc \quad\quad\quad
â \quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquareâ 
\quad

3. a | b ââkâZ\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z}ââkâZ \quad b = a â\cdotâ k
a | c ââqâZ\rightarrow \exists q \in \mathbb{Z}ââqâZ \quad c = b â\cdotâ q
\quad
âc=aâkâq\Rightarrow c = a \cdot k \cdot qâc=aâkâq
c=aâp\quad c = a \cdot pc=aâp
c=aâppâZ\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad c = a \cdot p \quad\quad\quad p\in\mathbb{Z}c=aâppâZ
â\Rightarrowâ a | c
â \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquareâ 
\quad

Division Algorithm

53=12/3\sqrt[3]{5} = 1{}^2/_3â3ââââ5âââ=1â2ââ/â3ââ Answer:5=3â1+2Answer: 5 = 3 \cdot 1 + 2Answer:5=3â1+2

Theorem


Let a, d âZ+\in\mathbb{Z^+}âZâ+ââ.
Then â!q,râZ\exists ! q,r \in \mathbb{Z}â!q,râZ
a = d â\cdotâ q + r \quadwhere r â¥\geqâ¥ 0

                                        a = divisor
                                        q = quotient
                                        r = remainder

e.g.
9Ã·3\quad\quad 9 \div 3 \quad\quad9Ã·3 remainder = 0
9Ã·4\quad\quad 9 \div 4 \quad\quad9Ã·4 remainder â \neqâ  0

Proof

1.dâ£a1. \quad d | a1.dâ£a âkâZa=dâk+0\exists k \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad a = d \cdot k + 0âkâZa=dâk+0 a=dâk+rwhere r=0a = d \cdot k + r \quad where\space r = 0a=dâk+rwhere r=0
\quad

2.dâ¤a2. \quad d \nmid a2.dâ¤a ârâZdâ£aâr\exists r \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad d | a - rârâZdâ£aâr âqâZaâr=dâq\exists q \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad a - r = d \cdot qâqâZaâr=dâq a=dâq+ra = d \cdot q + r \quada=dâq+r

e.g.
\quad\quad 4 â¤\nmidâ¤ 9
\quad4â£9â1â9â1=4â2\quad 4 | 9 - 1 \Rightarrow 9 - 1 = 4 \cdot 24â£9â1â9â1=4â2
â9=4â2+1\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \Rightarrow 9 = 4 \cdot 2 + 1â9=4â2+1

\quad
\quad

Definition: Mod


Let a=dâq+ra = d \cdot q + r \quada=dâq+r Then we say
amodd=ra \mod d = ramodd=r
when a divided by d results in remainder r.

Example 2
Which of the quotient and remainder when -11 is divided by 3?
      i)    101 mod 2 = 11   False   r = 11 > d = 2
     ii)    101 mod 11 = 2   True   101 = 11 * 9 + 2  d>r  
    iii)    11 mod 2 = 101   False  r = 101 > d = 2
     iv)    101 mod 2 = 1    True    101 = 2 * 50 + 1  d>r
Example 3
What are the quotient and remainder when -11 is divided by 3?
              -11 = 3 * -4 + 1
              q = -4
              r = 1

Definition: Div


Let a = dq + r \quad Then we say
a div d = q
When a divided by d has quotient q

Example 4
what is -11 div 3 ?
          -4

Modular Arithmetic

Definition: Congruence Module m


Let a,b âZ\in \mathbb{Z}âZ we say a is congruent to b module m, denoted
aâ¡b(modm)a \equiv b \left( \mod m \right)aâ¡b(modm)
if âkâZ\exists k \in \mathbb{Z}âkâZ such that a - b = m â\cdotâ k

i.e. \quad m | a - b

\quad

*Note

a mod d = r is NOT the same as a â¡\equivâ¡ b (mod m)

  • a mod d = r is a function

  • a â¡\equivâ¡ b (mod) m is a relation

    Recall:
            A = {1, 2, 3}
            B = {a, b, c}
 
    A relation:
            R â¤ A * B
            {(1,a), (1,b), (1,c)}
 
    A function adds the restriction that every input must have ONLY ONE output.

e.g.
4â¡1(mod3)\quad\quad 4 \equiv 1 (\mod 3)4â¡1(mod3) because 3â£(4â1)3 | (4-1)3â£(4â1)
4â¡3(mod1)\quad\quad 4 \equiv 3 (\mod 1)4â¡3(mod1) because 1â£(4â3)1 | (4-3)1â£(4â3)
5â¡3(mod2)\quad\quad 5 \equiv 3 (\mod 2)5â¡3(mod2) because 2â£(5â3)2 | (5-3)2â£(5â3)

5â¡1(mod2)\quad\quad 5 \equiv 1 (\mod 2)5â¡1(mod2) because 2â£(5â1)2 | (5-1)2â£(5â1)

      Notice 5 â¡ 3 and 5 â¡ 1 module 2, hence not a function.
 
      R: Relation that pairs congruent integers module 2
        = {(5,3), (5,1)...}
 
      F: Function
        = {(a,r) | a mod d = r}
 
      consider a = 5, d = 4
        F = {(5,r) | r = 5 mod 4}
          = {(5,1)}
          f(a,d) = r
Example 5
Determine which of the following are true?
      i)    7 â¡ 3 (mod 4)   True    4 | (7 - 3)
     ii)    7 â¡ 3 = 4       False   7 Ã· 3, remainder is 1
    iii)    15 â¡ 3 (mod 5)  False   5 â¤ (15 - 3)
     iv)    15 â¡ 5 (mod 2)  True    2 | (15 - 5)

Theorem


Let mâZ+m \in \mathbb{Z^+} \quadmâZâ+ââ if aâ¡b(modm)\quad a \equiv b (\mod m)aâ¡b(modm) and câ¡d(modm)c \equiv d (\mod m)câ¡d(modm)
i) a+câ¡b+d(modm)\quad a + c \equiv b + d ( \mod m)a+câ¡b+d(modm)
ii) acâ¡bd(modm)\quad\quad\quad ac \equiv bd ( \mod m)acâ¡bd(modm)

Proof


a+c=mk+b+mq+da + c = mk + b + mq + da+c=mk+b+mq+d
a+c=m(k+q)+(b+d)a + c = m(k + q) + (b + d)a+c=m(k+q)+(b+d)
a+c=ml+(b+d)a + c = ml + (b + d)a+c=ml+(b+d)
(a+c)â(b+d)=ml(a + c) - (b + d) = ml(a+c)â(b+d)=ml
AâB=mlA - B = mlAâB=ml
Aâ¡B(modm)A \equiv B (\mod m)Aâ¡B(modm)
a+c=(b+d)(modm)a + c = (b + d)(\mod m)a+c=(b+d)(modm)

Corollary

        a + b (mod m) = [(a mod m) + (b mod m)] mod m
        ab (mod m) = [(a mod m)(b mod m)] mod m

Arithmetic Modulo m

Definition: Zm={0,1,â¦,mâ1}\mathbb{Z}_m = \{0,1, \ldots, m-1\}Zâmââ={0,1,â¦,mâ1}

Operation on Zm\mathbb{Z}_mZâmââ

  • a+mb=(a+b)modma +_m b = (a + b) \mod ma+âmââb=(a+b)modm

  • aâmb=(aâb)modma \cdot_m b= (a \cdot b) \mod maââmââb=(aâb)modm

Ex: Let m = 11 Find


i)7+m9=(7+9)mod11â16mod11=5i) 7+_m9=(7+9) \mod 11 \rightarrow 16 \mod 11 = 5i)7+âmââ9=(7+9)mod11â16mod11=5
ii)7âm9=(7â9)mod11â63mod11=8ii) 7\cdot_m9=(7\cdot9) \mod 11 \rightarrow 63 \mod 11 = 8ii)7ââmââ9=(7â9)mod11â63mod11=8
